Having obtained my teacher accreditation from Ghent University in 2003, I have been a teacher for most of my professional life. Over the years, I have taught dozens of courses at various levels and institutions. 

Currently I'm teaching courses on Statistics, Corpus Linguistics, Historical English Linguistics, and Iconicity. I'm also involved in various courses related to research methodology, language variation and change and general linguistics. 

Outside academia, I enjoy teaching the martial art of karate at my Seikan Dojo (est. 2005). I'm a shidoin-level instructor in Koryu Uchinadi Kenpo-Jutsu under hanshi Patrick McCarthy (10th dan Koryu Uchinadi Kenpo-Jutsu). 

![Kwantitatieve onderzoekstechnieken taalwetenschap: Ludovic De Cuypere - Â© UGent, foto Christophe Vander Eecken](teaching_kwan_ugent.jpg)

One distinction that I've come to appreciate deeply is the one between teaching and lecturing. Presenting a slide deck or reading course notes in front of an audience is pretty straightforward. But good teaching is hard. Setting goals, designing lesson plans, and trying to get the best out of every student requires a deep commitment and is best fostered through years of experience.

The key ingredients that have worked best for me are having a clear overall structure, with well-defined learning goals and assesment criteria, and establishing a challenging yet safe learning environment. My teaching is mostly interactive and task-based. 

And just being able to tell a good story, arguably the most underrated teaching skill in the age of slide deck teaching. 

## Current courses

- Kwantitatieve onderzoekstechnieken in de taalwetenschap (UGent, BA3, 5 ECTS). Here is the website I wrote for this course: [Handboek](https://handboekstatistiektaalwetenschap.netlify.app/).
- Historical English Linguistics (VUB, MA, 6 ECTS)
- Variation and Change in English (VUB, BA3, 3 ECTS)
- Advanced English Linguistics (VUB, MA, 6 ECTS)
